description: From Latin proboscis, from Ancient Greek προβοσκίς (proboskís, “elephant's trunk”) literally "means for taking food," from προ- (pro-, “before”) +‎ βόσκω (bóskō, “to nourish, feed”), from the Proto-Indo-European root *gʷeh₃- from which also comes βοτάνη (botánē, “grass, fodder”).

definitionGroups.group: (anatomy) An elongated tube from the head or connected to the mouth, of an animal.

entries.meaning: (entomology, malacology) The tubular feeding and sucking organ of certain invertebrates like insects, worms and molluscs.
(informal, mildly humorous) A large or lengthy human nose.
